ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A general understanding of how an accountants mind works (e.g. credit vs debit), of accounting sheets and reports, and some good excel practice.
Reading financial statements, recreating accounting journals, understanding the Cash Flow Statement; lots of general accounting practices that are good to know
I learned about the time value of money, how to record financial transactions, and how to produce a set of financial statements.
The foundations and main principles of accounting

This course covered the time value of money, business basics, the basics of accountings, accounting and cash flows, and risk and expected return. We learned how to calculate discounted cash flows, how to analyze financial statements (Balance Sheets, Income Statements, Cash Flow Statements, etc.), and use the information extracted to make sense of a company's financials.

I developed a solid basic understanding of core accounting principles that will be helpful for a broad overview of the flow of money in and out of the businesses I plan to work with from a corporate sustainability standpoint. I feel that this course captured the correct level of complexity for YSE students focusing on Business and the Environment.
A broad overview of understanding discounted cash flows, financial statements, and accounting principles.
Learned more about accounting through problem sets, class material, and practice
Basic understanding of accounting and valuations
Debits/credits, how to make journal entries, how some T-accounts work
Intro on accounting, how to balance the books
I learned how to assess cash flows, look at financial statements better, and how to use Excel.
Basics of accounting and valuation.  Learned how to calculate the present value of future cash flows, read financial statements from corporations, and even some fun history of accounting events.
Balance sheets, income statements, statement of shareholders equity. Understanding how to account for liabilities and equities.
accounting
How to do accounting in a big way. A lot of learning was self-facilitated, but that's because I didn't go to class. I also really learned how to use Excel more. It's a good intro to accounting
I learned how to use Excel more efficiently and read financial statements

I learned all the fundamentals of how to fill out and analyze financial statements, including balance sheets, statements of shareholder equity, income statements, and both direct and indirect method cash flow statements.
I learned a lot about accounting.
Learned the very basics of accounting. Got a clear understanding of equity, liability,, and assets
Learned about financial statements.
Basic fundamentals of accounting, knowledge of financial terms such as assets, equities, and liabilities, and how to correctly identify transactions.
Learned a lot of genuine accounting principles. If you pair the class with corporate finance, theyll together be a great prep for finance interviews.
I learned to interpret financial statements and connect financial activities to accounting procedures.
I developed my accounting ability
This course helps you start to think about how accounting works and how the financial statements are made up.

Basics to accounting which is a skill Im grateful to learn. Professor Antle helps a lot with helpful homeworks, he also goes over jargon and some of the homeworks in lecture so its a bit of a reverse classroom. You do have homework due nearly every class but staying on top of it makes the class quite manageable. I found some of the lectures to drag and dont always help to improve your grade. The homeworks are definitely where you gain proficiency. Professor Antle is also always willing to answer questions and shows genuine interest to see his students learn which is refreshing to see.
The beginnings of accounting
I learned how to prepare a financial statement from basic transactions starting from journal entries to the balance sheet and finally to the financial statements.

This class is great! We did a broad overview of discounted cash flows in the beginning (figuring out stuff like interest rates vs. present value vs. future value) then moved onto the nitty gritty of reading/recording income statements. You also get pretty adept at navigating Excel as a financial tool.

I learned how to navigate Excel which is a useful skill to have throughout many fields. With the accounting aspect, it is important to understand how funds are distributed/invested and how it aligns with the assistance of excel.
I developed basic accounting understanding -- mainly debiting and crediting and less understanding of businesses through financial statements -- in an inefficient way
Accounting skills
I developed a foundational understanding of accounting, built from no knowledge of accounting or experience in the area.
understanding cash flows, reading financial statements, accounting basics

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
I liked the pace of the material, however it was challenging at times to keep up. 
I wished the format was reversed and the homework practice came AFTER the lecture - I felt so dumb trying to work my way through instructions we hadn't talked about yet.

Strengths: Prof. Antle is great

Weaknesses: grade is tough to figure out, hard to know whether to take the optional final/the odds that it will improve your grade

The strengths of this course are that it is relatively relaxed and has a grading system that would be appealing to some people. The weaknesses are that just doing the homework is not enough to really learn the material and it is easy to fall behind as a result.

Strengths: Rick outlines this course very well and makes learning and feedback fun and easy 
Weakness: The course felt very unorganized without a true syllabus outlining upcoming assignments and such. Got a sort of accurate syllabus about half-way though the semester

The excel assignments that we received were very thorough. They were very useful in getting practice in Excel, and it provided a learning environment where we could get help at any moment on terms or concepts that were confusing. The overall course was well-designed. As long as you go to class and engage with the material, you learn a lot.

From an engagement perspective, the course is actually really interesting. The professor manages to make the usually dry nature of accounting procedures interesting through engaging examples and stories, especially when illustrating what can go wrong and why in the scenarios discussed in the class. For students who have no prior engagement with the subject and will not be pursuing accounting as a career, it is an informative snapshot of the basic principles one should know.

The grading structure of the course was fairly unclear for a lot of the semester. I appreciate that the grading method for this course is unusual, and I am not suggesting changing the fundamental structure, but I would strongly suggest ensuring that homeworks are posted well in advance of their due dates, and ensuring that assignments posted to canvas are the ones that are required and for which it is possible to submit something. The emphasis in this course is on how well one has learned the material by the end of the semester, which is great, but it was frankly obscured by the syllabus/canvas assignment structure, and timing of homework assignment.

Rick provides a wealth of information on Canvas that really supports student learning. The assignments forced me to practice different skills until I felt comfortable with them, and I always felt like I could ask questions through the online message board or find the answers on Canvas or in recorded lectures. However, Rick gets a bit off topic in lectures and sometimes I got lost.

Strengths: if you do the optional final, you end up really understanding the basics of accounting 
weaknesses: it would be easy to not engage fully with the material given the grading system of the course and the automatic feedback in the problem sets
Sometimes it was hard to follow along, but the professor was always available to answer questions which was great
Weekly homework was helpful and the excel format was very helpful to correct ourselves. Less verbal explanations and more in class solving of problems is needed.
Needs to go more in depth with general accounting principles. Seems a little out of touch with practical accounting knowledge and too absorbed with the YALEIE.

Dr. Antle is a great professor and does an incredible job of incorporating real-world examples into lectures so that it doesn't feel like useless information that we're being fed. We didn't get much heads up on when assignments were released, so it was at the student's behest that they completed assignments on time. However, all assignments had feedback embedded into them, so if you made a mistake you could work your way through it because it was highlighted, rather than doing an assignment completely wrong with no indication of doing so.

Strengths:  Prof. Antle is awesome.  A great teacher and entertaining lecturer who made getting up early for class worth it.

Weaknesses: 8:45 AM lecture at the SOM made this class attractive to skip, especially with recorded lectures, though I was always happy when I attended.
It was sometimes challenging to understand what the main learning points Professor Antle was stressing.

8:45am at SOM is a huge negative. I'm surprised anyone went to class after the first couple of weeks. Rick Antle is also just the GOAT. He is really funny, but the class is really pretty slow at times. What is helpful though, is that the homework is a good tutor, you can learn a lot from just doing the homework

The material is presented very logically, and in a good order. The homework problems are fairly easy, since most of the time there is a checkbox where you can see if your answer is correct or not. As a tool for helping to learn how the statements are filled out, I actually think this is a great idea. I feel like I learned a lot both from lectures and from doing the homework. I will say, however, that sometimes in the middle of the semester the classes devolved into going over the homework, and as I didn't have trouble with the homework they were mostly useless for me, but I still enjoyed them and came to them.

strength - Prof. Antle is a great teacher. He is very friendly. The excel tool used for this class is fantastic. This tool gives clear feedback and makes learning easy.

Weakness - Sometimes, the recorded lectures were not immediately posted on canvas. A few lectures were not posted until 3-4 days after the lecture.
It's very early in the morning. Tough to get to class sometimes.
The Professor is a strength of the course as he is very enthusiastic about the curriculum. A weakness of the class is the lack of feedback from weekly quizzes and assignments.

Dr. Antle is an awesome guy, and he made accounting engaging. It wouldve been cool to have maybe a week or two of work on valuation, but as far as accounting goes the class was pretty solid as an intro.
Professor Antle was friendly and a good lecturer but the assignments were a bit monotonous at times.
This course was taught in a very well manner but the daily work was a bit much

The strengths of the course were the excel worksheets / workbooks that helped prepare and teach a lot of the material. It was great to learn by trial and error. Weaknesses were that much of the technical jargon would be difficult to fully understand alone or without previous knowledge of what some terms might mean.

Strengths - great professor (he's the best), relevant / hands on material 

Weaknesses - class is way too early considering it's in the SOM. Sort of mitigated by classes being posted online, but still would prefer later class time / closer to campus. You also have to really work to stay engaged in the class because of this -- really easy to start missing classes because it is so far away / early
Teach the class properly.
A course that I enjoyed, can't identify a weakness. Strength was how much the p sets on excel helped my understanding of the material.

The biggest weakness of the course is that Yale constrains classes to fit into semesters. I had taken a eight (8) hour online accounting class through Coursera taught by a Wharton professor, and I got more out of it than this semester long class. That class cost $70. I was hoping to learn some new stuff given the length. I feel like college education is in peril, and the failures of this class are emblematic of the cause. One, I can access the best teachers (not necessarily professors) in the world online for much cheaper (e.g. MIT posts lectures for free and Yale has worse STEM so why even bother). Two, I can engage with smart people online. I don't need to physically be (or virtually) in the Yale community to engage with bright people. Three, the semester, two day a week class system is constrained so that teaching and syllabus must fit to it; the material cannot dictate how it needs to be taught.

Professor for ACCT 270 had some good anecdotes, but seemed to drag the class on for no reason other than to fill the semester. There was no feedback on assignments. For some reason the final was on material that had never been taught the entire semester -- sifting through 10Ks. I wouldn't construct a class that way.

The course is really great, and the professor really engaging. The homework grading process is slightly unclear but overall it is a good course. Could be difficult to keep up with and stay on track with at times.

Not having a syllabus until half way through the semester and never knowing quite when we had homework and when we didn't made it really challenging to stay on top of the work and understnad what was expected of me. This made it hard to meaningfully engage with the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if they are interested in a basic understanding of accounting. It is manageable for non-math person.
Yes
I would recommend it if they are okay with the grading system. Otherwise, you need to be very motivated and be prepared to learn on your own as well as read the textbook.

Yes. This is a very good course to understand the fundamental principles of accounting and work in Excel. Rick makes it easy to learn these foundations, and the homeworks are very well structured to facilitate this learning.

Yes, this course provides useful life skills. Understanding the financials of companies is a step towards understanding how the world operates. If you're curious about that or just like quantitative work, this course would be great for you.
Yes. Overall the course is informative, enjoyable, and provides an appropriate amount of context and information for the core requirement it is supposed to fulfill.

Yes! But only if you really commit to learning the material. The classes themselves can feel a little off topic/tangential, but you ultimately get a solid understanding of accounting if you commit to taking the optional final and preparing fully for it.
Very practical skill to have
Unsure
Needs to go more in depth with general accounting principles. Seems a little out of touch with practical accounting knowledge and too absorbed with the YALEIE.

if you are going into a career in finance, this class can help you understand how the financial statements are created beyond what the prep books teach you. Also a great class if you're looking to cr/d something.

Take this course if you want to learn how to use Excel or if you think that finance is an industry you want to enter -- it's great for learning how to construct cash flows and to assess financial statements. This course will not teach you anything about personal finances that you cannot learn through a 5 minute YouTube video.
Yes-especially if you are interested in any sort of business role in the future.  It's one of the only YC courses that offer a glimpse into business practices.
Great course for a foundation of accounting but could be more rigorous.
Yes if you've never exposed to accounting before.
I would, accounting is a very important skill. Even being able to read and understand a 10-k is super important in any form of business. It's an easy grade, I really recommend taking it

Sure. This is a pretty low commitment course that will introduce you to Excel shortcuts and teach you how to read financial statements/balance sheets. This is one of the more applied classes available to Yale undergraduates, and Rick treats you like you're an MBA student. You feel like one too once the actual accounting part of the course begins, since you're reading real company statements and filling out accounting journals based on real company situations. Most of the class is plugging in numbers on Excel, and there isn't much of a discussion outlet or room for super creative problem-solving. Still, if you plan to go into finance and/or want a better understanding of what all the jargon on financial statements mean, this class would be a good choice.

If you're interested in this sort of work I would absolutely recommend. Also, if you are an econ major struggling to find passion in something, as I was, this class could also be for you! It convinced me to pursue accounting after graduation.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. The course provides a foundational understanding of accounting.
I'd recommend this class for those who do have never taken accounting, like me.
I would only recommend if you have no background knowledge.
Definitely would recommend
Yes, I would recommend it to anyone interested in learning the basics of accounting.
This class was low stress but I'm not sure how much I took out of it.
Yes for an introduction to the concepts. However, there is no deep dive into any particular subject.
Yes it was a very good into to the accounting world

I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn how financial statements are created. However, I would not recommend this class for people who want to learn how those financial statements relate to evaluating a company. The pace of the class is sometimes variable (starting slow and picking up speed quickly) but nothing too unmanageable.

I would! I think financial knowledge (especially accounting) is a great life skill for everyone. This works great as a fifth class to give you a real life skill. Additionally, one concern I had was I had already taken the class Financial Economics, and there was initially a lot of overlap. However, as the course dives deeper into income statements, the course material separates from the of Financial Economics (basically saying the first month overlaps, the rest of the course does not).
Don't take it unless you want an easy Credit/D/Fail
Yes, accounting basics are important to be well-rounded.

If you want to learn something, don't take this. Take this class: https://www.coursera.org/learn/wharton-accounting?specialization=finance-accounting for like $70 and a fourth of the time (~10 hours) -- you'll learn more. While you're at it, might as well drop out.
Yes. It was a good class where you could learn a lot without having background knowledge
This is a good beginning course for accounting.
I would not recommend this course to other students. I found the course disorganized and challenging to follow along.
